Cresce il consenso tra i Paesi UE per inserire il Corpo dei Guardiani della rivoluzione iraniana (IRGC) – i cosiddetti pasdaran – nell’elenco delle organizzazioni terroristiche, mentre, secondo quanto riferisce Ansa, i ministri degli Esteri dell’UE avrebbero dato il via libera a nuove sanzioni colpendo almeno 21 soggetti tra individui ed entità coinvolte nella repressione delle proteste iniziate a fine dicembre 2025 e 10 soggetti legati alla fornitura di armi alla Russia.
Secondo quanto affermato dall’Alta rappresentante per gli Affari esteri e la Politica di sicurezza dell’Unione europea, Kaja Kallas, al suo arrivo al Consiglio affari esteri in corso a Bruxelles, I Paesi UE, oltre alle nuove sanzioni, potrebbero trovare anche un accordo sull’inserimento dell’IRGC nella lista dei terroristi”, ha dichiarato Kaja Kallas ai giornalisti. “Se agisci come un terrorista, dovresti anche essere trattato come un terrorista”, ha affermato.
Martedì, l’Iran ha messo in guardia dalle “conseguenze distruttive” che avrebbe comportato se l’UE avesse proceduto con la designazione di paese terrorista, hanno riferito i media statali.
L’Alta rappresentante UE ha respinto l’idea che l’inserimento dell’IRGC nella lista nera avrebbe impedito una risoluzione diplomatica della crisi. “Si stima che, comunque, i canali diplomatici rimarranno aperti”, ha affermato, aggiungendo che il ministro degli Esteri iraniano Abbas Araghchi non sarà sanzionato in base alle nuove misure.
La decisione di inserire nella lista nera il corpo d’élite incaricato di garantire l’integrità della Repubblica Islamica e che risponde direttamente al leader supremo Ali Khamenei, arriva nel pieno della brutale repressione da parte delle autorità iraniane sui manifestanti, che secondo alcune stime ha causato la morte di decine di migliaia di persone e si è trasformata nella minaccia più grave al regime islamico degli ultimi decenni.

L’Italia spinge per l’inserimento dei Pasdaran nella lista UE delle organizzazioni terroristiche
L’Italia chiederà all’UE di inserire i Guardiani della rivoluzione (Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, i cosiddetti Pasdaran) nella lista delle organizzazioni terroristiche. Ad annunciarlo è il ministro degli Esteri e della Cooperazione internazionale, Antonio Tajani, in un messaggio su X. L’annuncio …

Nei giorni scorsi era stato il ministro degli Esteri e vicepresidente del Consiglio italiano, Antonio Tajani, ad annunciare l’intenzione dell’Italia di farsi promotrice dell’iniziativa. Parlando al suo arrivo al Consiglio affari esteri, Tajan ha confermato la “grande convergenza” tra i Paesi UE. Il ministro ha sottolineato due punti, il primo è una lista degli esponenti dell’IRGC che verranno sottoposti a sanzioni e sui vi sarebbe già un accordo politico. Il secondo punto – che avrebbe maggiori conseguenze sul piano internazionale – è quello di inserire l’intero corpo dei Guardiani della rivoluzione nell’elenco delle organizzazioni terroristiche, dove già figurano al Qaeda, lo Stato islamico e Hamas.

“Oggi ci sarà una decisione politica, poi la decisione concreta arriverà nel giro di qualche settimana”, ha affermato Tajani. “Mi pare però che ci sia una grande convergenza da parte di tutti i Paesi europei su questa decisione, dopo ciò che è accaduto nelle scorse settimane: una repressione che ha portato a migliaia e migliaia di morti tra i manifestanti”, ha aggiunto.
Da parte sua, il ministro degli Esteri francese Jean-Noël Barrot ha dichiarato ai giornalisti che il sostegno di Parigi alle nuove sanzioni dell’UE, rappresenta “un appello” a Teheran affinché rilasci i prigionieri politici, ponga fine alle esecuzioni e ripristini l’accesso a Internet per i 90 milioni di cittadini del paese. “Non può esserci impunità per i crimini commessi”, ha affermato Barrot, aggiungendo che l’Iran dovrebbe anche consentire “immediatamente” a due cittadini francesi che cercano rifugio presso l’ambasciata di Francia a Teheran di lasciare il Paese.
Il ministro degli Esteri spagnolo José Manuel Albares ha affermato che Madrid “condanna l’insensata repressione dei propri cittadini da parte del regime iraniano” e “si unirà a qualsiasi sanzione proposta contro il regime iraniano, comprese quelle che designano le Guardie Rivoluzionarie come terroristi”.

items.title: La Commissione stanzia 650 milioni in progetti strategici per la sicurezza energetica
items.description: La Commissione europea accelera sulla costruzione della nuova Unione dell’energia e mette sul tavolo quasi 650 milioni di euro per finanziare quattord
items.body:
By:  Cesare Ceccato  |  EURACTIV Italia    29 Gennaio 2026|13:18  (aggiornato:  29 Gennaio 2026|13:18 )            
            
                
        
    Palazzo Berlaymont, sede della Commissione europea [Bogdan Hoyaux - EC Audiovisual Service]            
        
             
        
            
                Stampa Email Facebook X LinkedIn WhatsApp Telegram

La Commissione europea accelera sulla costruzione della nuova Unione dell’energia e mette sul tavolo quasi 650 milioni di euro per finanziare quattordici progetti di infrastrutture energetiche transfrontaliere. Le risorse arrivano dal “Connecting Europe Facility” (CEF), lo strumento con cui l’Unione europea sostiene le grandi reti strategiche nei settori di trasporti, energia e digitale.
L’obiettivo è duplice: rafforzare la sicurezza energetica europea e ridurre i costi dell’energia per cittadini e imprese, aumentando al contempo l’integrazione delle rinnovabili e l’indipendenza strategica del continente, in una fase in cui Bruxelles punta a completare il distacco strutturale dalle importazioni russe.
L’investimento si inserisce nella nuova strategia lanciata con il “European Grids Package” e con l’iniziativa delle “Energy Highways”, le grandi dorsali energetiche continentali che dovranno sostenere l’elettrificazione e la transizione verde.
Non si tratta solo di cantieri e tralicci, le reti sono ormai una questione geopolitica. Come sottolinea la Commissione, senza interconnessioni efficienti non c’è mercato unico dell’energia, non c’è vera integrazione delle rinnovabili e non c’è autonomia strategica europea.
Il nuovo pacchetto sulle reti segna anche un cambio di metodo. La Commissione ha infatti previsto una pianificazione più europea, procedure accelerate e soprattutto una diversa ripartizione dei costi dei progetti transfrontalieri, per evitare che il peso ricada solo sui consumatori dei Paesi in cui le infrastrutture vengono fisicamente costruite.
I progetti selezionati hanno ottenuto nel 2024 lo status di “Progetti di interesse comune” (PCI) e “Progetti di mutuo interesse” (PMI) nell’ambito del “Quadro strategico delle reti transeuropee per l’energia” (TEN-E).
Dei quasi 650 milioni stanziati, circa 470 milioni saranno destinati a sei progetti elettrici, incluse le smart grid. Il finanziamento più consistente – 180 milioni di euro – andrà alla Spagna per il progetto “AGUAYO II“, una centrale idroelettrica a pompaggio reversibile sotterranea che punta a migliorare la capacità di stoccaggio dell’energia rinnovabile senza impatti ambientali aggiuntivi.
Un altro capitolo politicamente sensibile riguarda la sicurezza delle infrastrutture critiche. Quasi 113 milioni serviranno a rafforzare la protezione delle reti nei Paesi baltici e in Polonia nel quadro della sincronizzazione con il sistema europeo, anche contro minacce fisiche e cyber. È la prima volta che il CEF finanzia su questa scala la resilienza delle infrastrutture energetiche.
In Slovacchia poi arriveranno 63 milioni per modernizzare l’impianto di Čierný Váh, uno dei primi in Europa a combinare accumulo idroelettrico e batterie. Tra Bulgaria e Romania partirà invece un grande progetto di reti intelligenti da oltre 100 milioni per modernizzare e digitalizzare trasmissione e distribuzione. Infine, sarà finanziato con oltre 9 milioni la “Green Energy Interconnector” tra Grecia ed Egitto, e con poco più di 1 milione la linea interna tra Westtirol e Zell in Austria.
Sul fronte più strettamente legato all’energia, il pacchetto prende in considerazione anche l’idrogeno, considerato da Bruxelles una leva chiave per la decarbonizzazione dell’industria pesante. Oltre 176 milioni di euro saranno destinati a tale scopo.
Il progetto simbolo ha sede in Germania, dove 120 milioni saranno stanziati per finanziare il primo grande impianto sotterraneo transfrontaliero di stoccaggio dell’idrogeno a Gronau, che segna anche la prima volta in cui il CEF finanzia direttamente lavori su simili infrastrutture, e non solo studi preparatori.
Altri progetti in Austria, Francia, Paesi Bassi, Slovacchia e Bulgaria riceveranno fondi per studi e progettazione, a conferma che il settore sta passando dalla fase sperimentale a quella industriale.

Eolico e solare superano i fossili in Europa, ma il gas resta un rischio strategico
Nel 2025 l’Unione europea ha raggiunto un traguardo simbolico nella transizione energetica: per la prima volta eolico e solare hanno prodotto più elettricità dei combustibili fossili. Secondo l’ultimo rapporto di Ember, think tank specializzato sui sistemi energetici, le due fonti …

L’investimento si inserisce in un quadro più ampio. All’inizio dello scorso anno, la Commissione aveva annunciato investimenti per 1,25 miliardi di euro in quarantuno progetti energetici strategici. Il tema ritorna nel rapporto Draghi sulla competitività. “Senza infrastrutture comuni”, si legge nel rapporto, “la transizione verde rischia di diventare un freno, anziché un moltiplicatore di crescita”.
Dopo il via libera degli Stati membri nel comitato CEF del 15 gennaio, l’adozione formale è attesa nelle prossime settimane. I contratti di finanziamento saranno gestiti dal CINEA, l’agenzia europea per il clima, l’infrastruttura e l’ambiente, mentre il prossimo bando è previsto per il secondo trimestre del 2026.

items.title: Cosa ci dice la frana di Niscemi sulla prevenzione ambientale e climatica in Italia
items.description: Mentre le istituzioni gestiscono l'emergenza e la magistratura indaga per disastro colposo, gli esperti avvisano: mancano gli strumenti per prevenire.
items.body:
2 miliardi di danni, cosa ci lascia la Tempesta Harry

L’Italia frana sempre di più e non abbiamo una cartografia geologica adeguata
		
		
			L’alluvione a San Felice a Cancello, in Campania, conferma la fragilità del nostro territorio. Ma le misure di prevenzione stentano ad arrivare. 
		
		
			 Ambiente
			30 agosto 2024
			
				di Simone Santi

Altro che idrogeologico, quello dell’Italia è un rischio idrogeocementizio
		
		
			Gli ingegneri naturalistici parlano di “rischio idrogeocementizio” anziché idrogeologico per sottolineare l’incidenza dell’edilizia sulle alluvioni. 
		
		
			 Ambiente
			22 novembre 2023
			
				di Simone Santi

“Nera che porta via”, viaggio in Romagna a due settimane dall’alluvione
		
		
			Siamo stati in Emilia-Romagna, dove i cittadini provano a recuperare ciò che resta delle loro case dopo l’alluvione, insieme a migliaia di volontari.
		
		
			 Italia
			30 maggio 2023

Cosa dobbiamo imparare dall’alluvione delle Marche del 2022
			
			
				Il problema è sociale, non scientifico: il caso dell’alluvione delle Marche del 2022 è lo specchio del rischio di disastri ambientali causati da abusivismo edilizio e mancata cura del territorio.

Italia

19 dicembre 2022

Nel 2020 dobbiamo arrestare il consumo di suolo. Lo sostiene anche la Corte dei conti
			
			
				Almeno il 30% del patrimonio edilizio esistente è vuoto, la popolazione è in calo, ma si continua a costruire. Serve una legge per arrestare il consumo di suolo: l’appello arriva anche dalla Corte dei conti.

Ambiente

14 gennaio 2020

Plastic tax, Green new deal, ecobonus: cosa prevede per l’ambiente la legge di bilancio 2020
			
			
				Il Parlamento ha approvato la manovra finanziaria per il 2020: vale 32 miliardi di euro. Molti i commi che riguardano ambiente e clima: arriva la plastic tax, un pacchetto di misure per il Green new deal, incentivi per la rigenerazione. Ma non si potrà più chiedere lo sconto dell’ecobonus in fattura.

Cambiamenti climatici

24 dicembre 2019

L’Italia è fatalista, serve un piano di adattamento secondo il geologo Antonello Fiore
			
			
				Piogge, crolli, esondazioni. L’Italia appare nella morsa dei cambiamenti climatici, ma anche di dissesto idrogeologico e mancata prevenzione. Per il presidente della Società italiana di geologia ambientale, Antonello Fiore, ci vuole un programma decennale per rimediare.

Cambiamenti climatici

28 novembre 2019

A un anno dalla tempesta che ha devastato l’Italia, l’emergenza climatica non è cessata
			
			
				Come dimostrano gli eventi meteorologici estremi dello scorso autunno, all’Italia serve un piano nazionale di adattamento ai cambiamenti climatici. Il governo dichiari subito l’emergenza climatica.

Ambiente

29 ottobre 2019

Consumo di suolo, in Italia cementificata un’area grande come piazza Navona ogni 2 ore
			
			
				Nel 2017 il cemento è aumentato di 52 chilometri quadrati, anche in zone a rischio idrogeologico. La legge per lo stop al consumo di suolo entro il 2050 è ferma da due anni in parlamento.

Italia

17 luglio 2018

items.title: CIB e Farming for Future Foundation a Fieragricola di Verona, dal 4 al 7 febbraio
items.description: Il CIB – Consorzio Italiano Biogas, insieme alla Farming for Future Foundation, dal 4 al 7 febbraio sarà presente a Fieragricola (stand B5, pad.
items.body:
CIB e Farming for Future Foundation a Fieragricola di Verona, dal 4 al 7 febbraio

29 Gennaio 2026

Il CIB – Consorzio Italiano Biogas, insieme alla Farming for Future Foundation, dal 4 al 7 febbraio sarà presente a Fieragricola (stand B5, pad. 11) presso il Palaexpo a Verona, con diverse opportunità di confronto e approfondimento dedicati ai temi delle biomasse e sostenibilità, del digestato, fino alle ultime novità del settore del biogas e del biometano agricolo. Le giornate fieristiche saranno scandite da eventi e workshop tecnici che tratteggeranno e approfondiranno diversi aspetti del ruolo della diffusione della digestione anaerobica in agricoltura. Accanto alle iniziative in area Forum, si affiancherà tre tour guidati alla scoperta delle “Macchine dell’agricoltura sostenibile” in esposizione nel Padiglione 11 – Agroenergie, per approfondire e scoprire le soluzioni più innovative in ambito di mobilità sostenibile in agricoltura, logistica e fertilizzazione organica.

items.title: ReMaRe, il progetto per rigenerare l’Adriatico meridionale
items.description:
L’obiettivo è unire sostenibilità ambientale, sociale ed economica per rigenerare ecosistemi fragili come le praterie di Posidonia oceanica
The post R
items.body: In evidenza WWF Italia: 60 anni per la natura In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il leopardo delle Nevi In evidenza Adotta una specie Non si può proteggere il mare senza ascoltare chi lo vive e lo respira ogni giorno. Con questa convinzione si è conclusa un’intensa quattro giorni di lavori, dal 19 al 22 gennaio, tra le province di Brindisi e Lecce, segnando un passo fondamentale per il progetto “ReMaRe – Recupero Marino e costiero per comunità Resilienti”. Il percorso, coordinato dal WWF Italia nell’ambito del programma internazionale ELSP e finanziato dalla Fondazione Arcadia, ha coinvolto oltre 80 stakeholder in un processo partecipativo ambizioso. L’obiettivo è unire sostenibilità ambientale, sociale ed economica per rigenerare ecosistemi fragili come le praterie di Posidonia oceanica, il coralligeno e le dune costiere. Un approccio “dal basso” Il cuore dell’iniziativa è un approccio “dal basso”: pescatori, operatori turistici, istituzioni e associazioni sono stati chiamati non solo a individuare le criticità del territorio, ma a diventarne parte attiva nella soluzione. Dagli incontri, organizzati con il prezioso supporto dei partner locali del progetto (Area Marina Protetta di Torre Guaceto, Parco delle Dune Costiere, Comune di Lecce, Comune di Vernole e Oasi WWF le Cesine), che hanno toccato le relative località, sono emerse necessità chiare e trasversali. Tra le priorità individuate figurano il rafforzamento della legalità contro le attività illecite, la creazione di tavoli di co-gestione tra i diversi attori e la necessità di infrastrutture adeguate alle comunità di pesca artigianale, così come di dispositivi volti alla tutela dell’ambiente come telecamere, campi boe per proteggere la Posidonia, passerelle e steccati per proteggere le dune. Particolare attenzione è stata posta al trovare una soluzione per una gestione integrata ed efficiente della Posidonia spiaggiata e al modo in cui viene percepita dalla popolazione: formazione e sensibilizzazione di istituzioni, operatori, turisti e cittadini sull’importanza della biodiversità marina e sui corretti comportamenti sono emerse come necessità urgenti e trasversali in tutto il territorio. L’App SMART Le Guardie Ecologiche Volontarie (GEV), istruite dal WWF in collaborazione con la Provincia di Brindisi e il Consorzio di Gestione di Torre Guaceto, sono state coinvolte anche nella presentazione e introduzione all’uso dell’App SMART (Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool), uno strumento digitale pensato per la segnalazione di attività illecite in mare, con particolare attenzione alla tutela ambientale e alla sicurezza, promosso sul territorio grazie al progetto H2020 Permagov dedito a migliorare la performance della governance marine in Europa. L’obiettivo è potenziare la capacità di rilevare e riportare irregolarità o comportamenti dannosi per l’ambiente marino nelle AMP e nelle Zone Speciali di Conservazione attraverso la tecnologia mobile. L’elevata partecipazione GEV  conferma l’importanza del presidio territoriale e del ruolo attivo della cittadinanza nella tutela dell’ambiente. La scelta del nome Il primo gesto di partecipazione attiva e di coinvolgimento dal basso è stato lasciare la scelta del nome alle comunità partecipanti, che hanno proposto e votato il nome che meglio rappresentava il loro sentire. Sono le comunità locali che hanno, quindi, scelto il nome  ReMaRe (Recupero Marino e costiero per comunità Resilienti) che da adesso in avanti sarà l’identificativo di questo progetto. Il progetto “ReMaRe” è parte del programma internazionale EndangeredLandscapes & SeascapesProgramme (ELSP), finanziato dalla Fondazione Arcadia e coordinato da WWF Italia e WWF Mediterraneo. L’iniziativa opera lungo la costa meridionale adriatica pugliese, su un’area di circa 52.000 ettari, con l’obiettivo di ripristinare e tutelare habitat marini e costieri prioritari e rafforzare una rete ecologicamente connessa ed efficacemente gestita di aree tutelate. Il progetto contribuisce al raggiungimento degli obiettivi europei al 2030 per la biodiversità e all’attuazione della Nature Restoration Law, promuovendo una gestione partecipata che coinvolga istituzioni, comunità locali e mondo scientifico per garantire benefici ambientali, climatici e socio-economici duraturi. Maggiori informazioni sono disponibili alla pagina https://www.endangeredlandscapes.org/project/apulia/ 31 Ottobre 2025 Tra mare e terra nasce "Sud Adriatico" Il nuovo progetto per il ripristino del paesaggio marino e costiero della Puglia meridionale 7 Giugno 2024 GenerAzioneMare del WWF per salvare il Capitale Blu Con centinaia di attivisti tra volontari, ricercatori, pescatori, subacquei, prende il via la fase estiva della Campagna OurNature Giovanna Quaglieri 7 Luglio 2017 Dieci cose da sapere sulla tartaruga Caretta caretta Con le sue circa 17.000 specie viventi, il Mediterraneo è uno dei mari più ricchi di biodiversità al mondo, ma durante il periodo estivo, c’è una specie in particolare, che più rappresenta il nostro mare: la tartaruga marina. … Giulia Ciarlariello 23 Agosto 2019 Gli squali sentinella nell'Adriatico lanciano segnali ai ricercatori In questi giorni i primi 4 squali ‘sentinella’  della specie Verdesca (Prionace glauca) stanno nuotando nelle acque del basso Adriatico ‘raccontando’ in diretta dettagli sul loro comportamento, come durata di immersione e spostamenti, grazie a speciali TAG satellitari precedentemente applicati dai…

The catalogue contains a comprehensive list of information products relevant to the various Copernicus services.

On January 27, 2025, clumps of solidified vegetable oil were found along a 25 km stretch of coastline on Finland’s Hanko Peninsula. While not toxic, the substance posed risks to wildlife. Suspecting it came from a passing vessel’s cargo tank wash, Finnish authorities launched an investigation,…

The COSNORTH-SEMAR DSS is a decision-support system developed to enhance maritime surveillance and law enforcement along Spain’s northern coast. Created in collaboration with the Guardia Civil, it combines environmental data, vessel tracking, and predictive modeling in a user-friendly platform…

Planning a sailing route based on weather used to be hard and needed expert skills. Many sailors didn’t use it because it was too complicated. SailRouting changes that by offering an easy online tool that shows weather-based routes in just a few clicks — no setup needed.

With SailRouting…

This study examines the environmental conditions near the Motagua River mouth in the Caribbean Sea, focusing on mangrove resilience, plastic pollution, and water turbidity. Photosynthesis data reveals magrove strong resistance with high absorption values in northern and southern regions, though…

💨 On 26 Jan, a dense plume of Saharan dust moved N, affecting air quality across large parts of Greece, the Balkans & SE Mediterranean. CAMS data shows higher dust concentrations in dark 🟠 and 🔴 tones.🔗 https://t.co/So5CxY1FLy#ImageOfTheDay #CopernicusEU pic.twitter.com/siWC8e51wf

🌊 At the 18th EU Space Conference, @CMEMS_EU & @MercatorOcean showcased how ocean data supports safety, navigation, port infrastructure & maritime security - providing trusted ocean intelligence to help manage real-world risks. @CostasKadis @KubiliusA🔗 https://t.co/ufUx5eQrHq pic.twitter.com/cMftdSBiee

🔥 Wildfires broke out across central Chile 🇨🇱, prompting authorities to declare a state of emergency in the Ñuble & Biobío regions. CEMS was activated on 21 Jan to provide fire mapping.🔗 https://t.co/O2abLl7ERR#ImageOfTheDay #CopernicusEU pic.twitter.com/3GWaxhT2NF

Copernicus, previously known as GMES (Global Monitoring for Environment and Security), is the  European Union's Earth observation programme. The views expressed on this website are those of the authors and do not necessarily represent those of the European Commission.

Copernicus is the Earth Observation component of the European Union’s space programme, looking at our planet and its environment for the benefit of Europe’s citizens.

items.title: Current and projected impacts of extreme climate events on winter wheat yield in Northern China
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 29 January 2026

Current and projected impacts of extreme climate events on winter wheat yield in Northern China
                    Ruiyun Zeng1,2,3, Xiaomao Lin 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-0804-78531, Gretchen F. Sassenrath1, Stephen M. Welch1 & …Fengmei Yao3 Show authors

Communications Earth & Environment

volume 7, Article number: 100 (2026)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Climate and Earth system modellingClimate-change impactsClimate-change mitigation

AbstractExtreme climate events (ECEs) pose substantial threats to global food security, particularly impacting winter wheat yields in Northern China. Here, we examine historical and projected effects of ECEs on wheat production across three sub-regions. Using statistical models and cropping system simulations, we quantify yield losses driven by individual and compound stressors under historical and future climate scenarios. Historically, post-anthesis compound hot-dry events and spring heat stress caused the greatest yield reductions in the north and middle sub-regions, whereas compound freeze-dry events dominated in the south. By 2080-2100, rising post-anthesis compound hot-dry events are projected to further reduce yields. Heat stress is expected to offset the benefits of reduced freeze stress, particularly in the cooler north sub-region, where its effects are more pronounced than in the warmer south. These findings highlight the urgent need for region-specific adaptation strategies to sustain wheat production under climate change.

IntroductionAs the global population and living standards drive the increasing demand for food, projections suggest that food production will need to double by 20501,2. However, climate change poses challenges to food security with changes in temperature and precipitation patterns, substantially affecting crop growth environments and final yields3. Under continued greenhouse gas emissions, the frequency and intensity of extreme climate events (ECEs) are expected to increase, exerting predominantly negative impacts on agricultural systems and likely causing yield reductions for many major crops4,5. Consequently, understanding the interactions between key climate factors and their impacts on crop productivity is critical for developing strategies to mitigate climate-induced risks to agriculture.ECEs cause large variations in daily and seasonal temperature and precipitation, and these occurrences often cause varying degrees of yield losses. Wheat is most vulnerable to heat stress during the reproductive phase from anthesis to maturity6,7. Heat stress affects crop growth and yield by reducing photosynthetic rate and carbon assimilation8, shortening grain filling duration9, and reducing grain number10. Freeze stress likely affects crop growth and development, thereby reducing production11,12. A sudden cold temperature exposure during the sensitive stem elongation phase can reduce the number of tillers and spikes. As shown in a two-year field experiment, wheat yield loss from spring freeze stress is highly correlated with the reduction of tiller and spike number13. A five-day spring freeze episode at the jointing stage could lead to a 5–14% wheat yield loss. In addition, drought is often the main constraint on winter wheat yields in rainfed systems4. Drought can restrain root growth and leaf expansion, shorten grain filling duration, and limit carbon allocation in crops14,15. Long-term drought can cause complete crop failure and can sharply reduce global crop yields by an average of 10%4. What makes this more challenging is that various ECEs can interact during the critical growing stages, namely, compound ECEs can lead to unique and even greater negative impacts than individual events16. Such interactions can increase the susceptibility of one ECE to subsequent deleterious environmental conditions, ultimately intensifying final crop yield reduction.Two distinct methods have been widely used to examine relationships between climate and yield: statistical models and process-based crop models. Statistical models use various regression methods to quantify the impacts of changes in climate indices on crop yield17,18,19,20. However, a major limitation of statistical models is that they usually provide a simple evaluation of impacts, rather than revealing the deeper underlying mechanisms required to better inform adaptation strategies18,21. Process-based crop models are essential tools designed to assess the effects of multiple climate factors on crop growth and yield22,23,24. They can dynamically simulate the process of crop growth, development, and yield formation, and accurately express the complex interactions between crop growth, environmental factors, and management practices. However, most crop models have been developed under relatively stable climate conditions. The effects of ECEs on crops are generally oversimplified and only vaguely described, leading to inaccurate simulation results under extreme climate conditions18,25. Given the limitations of both process-based crop models and statistical regression models, the value of combining both models to achieve complementary advantages is gaining recognition as a more robust approach to determining the impacts of ECEs on crop performance and production.Winter wheat is a major crop in the Huang-Huai-Hai (HHH) Plain of China (Fig. 1a), contributing 21% of global food supplies, and 80% of China’s wheat production26, making it important for both domestic and international food security. The HHH wheatbelt is characterized by variable climate conditions, featuring north-south gradients in both temperature and precipitation across the region. Average growing season temperatures in HHH had a warming trend occurring across the entire region over the past 40 years (Fig. 1b) but presented a declining trend in average total precipitation (Fig. 1c). ECEs, including heat, freeze, and drought, frequently impact China’s agricultural production. Xiao et al. (2018)27 reported an increasing probability of spring freeze since the 1970s, while Liu et al. (2014)28 projected that drought and heat stress will intensify under a changing climate in Northern China. These recurrent ECEs are expected to amplify the interannual variability of wheat yields, posing a severe threat to food security. While numerous studies have examined the relationship between ECEs and crop production in China29,30, a systematic analysis and modeling of how different ECEs affect wheat yields across various biological growth phases remains unexplored. There is thus a need to elucidate the linkage between ECEs over the agricultural phases of relevance to crop growth. Moreover, understanding how these impacts may evolve under future climate scenarios is critical. Therefore, to examine the relationship more fully between climate and wheat productivity, the HHH was divided into three wheat planting sub-regions based on the eco-climatic conditions, delineated as the north (NS), middle (the Huang-Huai, HHS), and south (the middle-lower reaches of Yangzi River, MYS). Our study aims to (1) assess associations between historical ECEs and wheat yield losses during different crop growth phases in the three main wheat-growing sub-regions of China, and (2) evaluate the potential impacts of ECEs on future wheat yields under climate scenarios of SSP1-2.6, SSP3-7.0, and SSP5-8.5.Fig. 1: Characterization of the study region.a Winter wheat planting patterns (green background) across each sub-region (north (NS); middle (Huang-Huai, HHS); south (middle-lower reaches of Yangzi River, MYS)). Circles are meteorological observations distributed at irrigated (blue) and rainfed (orange) sites, and red stars indicate locations of experimental sites. b, c Time series of mean (solid lines) of the winter wheat growing season temperature (b) and precipitation (c) during 1980 to 2019. The dashed lines in (b) and (c) represent the linear trends, with shaded areas representing 95% confidence intervals.Full size imageResultsResponse of wheat yield to extreme climate indicesWe use a linear mixed-effects model that includes freezing (FDD), heat (EDD), dry (CDD), compound hot-dry (CHD), and compound freeze-dry (CFD) events to estimate the sensitivity of wheat yield to different extreme climate indices in the winter wheatbelt (Fig. 2). Due to the limited availability of observed yields, regression models were applied for extreme climate indices spanning from 2000 to 2019. In general, the coefficients for heat stress were larger in magnitude than for freezing stress, with heat stress during the spring (EDDVP) having a stronger negative impact on yield (0.44%) than during the post-anthesis phase (EDDRP) (0.08%) (Fig. 2a). The estimated sensitivity of wheat yield to consecutive dry events (CDD) was negative during the vegetative and reproductive phases, with higher values corresponding to a greater sensitivity of yield to CDD (Fig. 2b). Among all the CDD terms, an increase of dryness during the reproductive (CDDRP) phase was associated with the largest yield loss, with the increase in CDDRP reducing yield up to 4.1%. We found there was a consistent negative response to yield when single extreme climate indices were included in the compound extreme climate indices (Fig. 2c). We observed a decreased resilience of yields to extreme climate indices over time, with a trend of −0.06 kg % yr-1 from 2000 to 2009. The results showed that the variation in yields could be explained by climate indices, with distinct negative effects observed across the three sub-regions (Fig. 3, Supplementary Table 1). In the north (NS), heat stress during the reproductive phase (EDDRP) and dryness during the vegetative phase (CDDVP) caused comparable wheat yield loss. Meanwhile, the heat stress during the spring (EDDVP) led to a larger yield loss, with the increase in EDDVP reducing yield by 6.4% (Fig. 3a). This was consistent with previous findings that high temperatures in the spring just before or during flowering affect seed set, cause accelerated leaf senescence, and result in larger declines in wheat yield31. Also, the yield loss caused by dry events during the vegetative phase (CDDVP) was greater than that caused by dry events during the other two phases. Compound hot-dry events (CHDRP) caused a considerably larger yield loss of 7.5% compared to individual counterparts. In the middle (HHS), there was no difference in the yield loss caused by compound hot-dry extremes (CHDRP) and heat stress (EDDVP) (Fig. 3b). The average yield loss caused by consecutive dry days (CDD) in the HHS was lower than that in the NS sub-region. However, compound freeze-dry events (CFD) tended to induce greater stress on wheat yield in the south sub-region (MYS), resulting in a yield loss of 12.0% during the dormancy (CFDDP) and 2.5% during the vegetative (CFDVP) phases (Fig. 3c). The time series of ECEs was calculated (Supplementary Figs. 1 and 2) and found that future heat events were projected to largely increase. By the 2080s, spring heat events (HDVP) were projected to increase under the three climate scenarios from 1 to 2 days (SSP1–2.6), 4 days (SSP3–7.0), and 6 days (SSP5–8.5). Heat events during the reproductive (HDRP) were expected to increase by an average of 5 days (SSP1–2.6), 11 days (SSP3–7.0), and 16 days (SSP5–8.5), indicating heat especially during the reproductive period, as warming increased (Supplementary Fig. 3). During the baseline period, the spatial variations in freeze events (FD) were similar, with higher freeze events in the north (NS) compared to the middle (HHS) and south (MYS) sub-regions. Regionally, FDDP was projected to decrease more than FDVP for three climate scenarios across nearly all of NS. Nonetheless, future FD was projected to increase slightly over the central areas of HHS and MYS under the SSP1-2.6 scenario (Fig. 4j and n). Estimated sensitivity of yield to higher temperatures (EDD) suggested that crop models could better account for heat stress effects on wheat yield (Fig. 6a, b). It should be noted that relatively large discrepancies existed in freezing stress between statistical and process-based modeling (Fig. 6c). Process-based crop models might not adequately simulate the growth and development dynamics, and yield formation of wheat under low-temperature stress, suggesting possible flaws or gaps in model representation of the freezing stress effects on crop yield10,32. This may arise because crop phenology sub-models were developed with field experiment data, which were scarce under extreme conditions, especially extreme low temperature conditions. For yield changes due to drought effects, crop models generally reproduced the direction of yield change, but the magnitude of yield change estimated by crop models differed substantially from the one estimated from yield statistics (Fig. 6f). The comparison of the negative extreme climate effects estimated with the process-based simulated yields and yield statistics reveals that the statistics models do not reproduce the process model-derived negative response of yield to ECEs. For yield changes due to heat stress (EDD) and compound hot-dry extremes (CHD), statistical models generally reproduce the directions of yield change, but the magnitudes of yield change were smaller than estimated from the process-based model, with the largest discrepancies observed in the NS. The ensemble mean of EDD effects suggests that by 2080–2100, warmer climate results in yield declines of 5.6  ±  1.5% (SSP1-2.6), 7.7  ±  2.2% (SSP3-7.0), and 9.4  ±  3.2% (SSP5-8.5) primarily due to temperature stress in spring (EDDVP). However, such yield decline would likely be offset by yield benefits due to reduced exposure to freezing stress in the MYS. Future warming is projected to lead to declines in drought exposure and reduced drought effects. However, future warming would lead to an increase in compound hot-dry events during the reproductive growth phase (CHDRP), primarily driven by substantially rising heat stress, thereby reducing yields. This effect would decrease future wheat yield more in the NS than HHS and MYS sub-regions, and these declining yields were greater as the climate scenarios increased in intensity.Fig. 7: Impact of extreme climate indices on wheat yields by 2080-2100 under SSP1-2.6, SSP3-7.0, and SSP5-8.5 scenarios.a Estimated effects of future changes in extreme climate indices on wheat yields, derived from both the process-based and statistical models for the north (NS) sub-region. Solid circles represent estimated mean coefficients from the process-based model, and asterisks represent those from the statistical model; vertical bars denote the 95% confidence intervals.Full size imageDiscussionComparison of differences in historical and future extreme climate indicesTemperature plays a multifaceted role in the development and productivity of winter wheat, intricately influencing processes such as vernalization, photosynthesis, and respiration33,34. Winter wheat exhibits varying temperature thresholds and sensitivities across its growth phases. Heat stress (EDD), for instance, has been more prevalent in the cooler north sub-region compared to the warmer south sub-region (Fig. 4). Further, drought remains a major constraint across the wheatbelt in China. Climate change-induced water scarcity places huge pressure on agriculture35,36,37, with yields highly susceptible to irregular drought stress during critical growth phases38,39. Our findings indicate that consecutive dry days (CDD) are projected to decrease overall; however, an increasing trend during the planting to November period was particularly evident in the south sub-region. This aligns with Ji and Kang (2015)40, who reported that dry events in southern China is predicted to increase by the end of the 21st century. While drought events are projected to remain relatively stable, heat events are expected to rise markedly in the future (Supplementary Fig. 3). Consequently, climate projections suggest that warmer post-anthesis compound hot-dry events (CHD) are primarily driven by rising heat stress, consistent with the findings in Australia, where recurrent drought and increasing heat events contribute to rising frequencies of CHD41.Freeze events, defined by diverse temperature thresholds across growth phases, persistently pose substantial challenges for winter wheat. These events were mainly divided into early freeze (germination and dormancy phases) and late freeze (vegetative phase). Between 2000 and 2019, freeze occurrences during dormancy (CFDDP) and vegetative (CFDVP) were frequent. Freeze damage during germination primarily affects the freezing of new leaves and has little impact on the wheat’s reproductive organs and yield42. However, global warming has led to pronounced warm and cold fluctuations during the stem elongation stage, exacerbating spring freeze events27. This was consistent with the previous study, which showed that spring freezes are common in the Australian wheatbelt and regularly cause serious damage to wheat production43. However, future projections indicate more reductions in freeze events across the north and much of the wheatbelt sub-regions. Similarly, interactions between drought and freeze events are expected to decline across multiple growth phases, further altering the risk landscape for winter wheat production in Northern China.Wheat yield sensitivity to extreme climate indicesLarge disparities in the wheat yield sensitivity of ECEs were observed across the sub-regions. Projected warming trends in heat stress suggest a greater decrease in yield in the north and middle sub-regions, which is consistent with results found in Australia41. Freeze events were not equally distributed during the growing season, and the timing of the occurrence of freeze events should not be neglected when assessing the impact of freeze on crops. The susceptibility of crops to freezing was found to increase with the specific growth phase. The negative sensitivity of wheat to freeze stress was stronger in the south sub-region. Thus, warming trends in freeze were beneficial to wheat growth as they reduced cold injury and freeze damage to winter wheat seedlings. Decreasing trends in freeze had positive effects on yield, with spring freeze contributing more to yield reductions. Additionally, we observed that the statistical model tended to predict less negative yield response to temperature extremes than the process-based model. One potential explanation is that statistical models reflect aggregate outcomes across diverse environments, and Northern China is characterized by relatively lower humidity, so that it may experience greater evaporative cooling under warming conditions44. Therefore, this would reduce heat impacts. However, this does not necessarily imply the statistical model performed greater accuracy, as the statistical model also captures interactions between temperature and humidity.Our comparison of yield sensitivities to precipitation extremes revealed additional discrepancies. This divergence is consistent with earlier findings23, which showed that process-based and statistical models often differ in their estimated precipitation sensitivities. This may be due to the fact that process-based models operate with fixed soil parameters45 and assumed initial soil water conditions46, while the statistical models are aggregated across a wide range of field conditions and soil types. Moreover, process-based models may empirically overemphasize the role of precipitation47 while overlooking other field-level constraints, such as heavy precipitation within a short time, waterlogging, or lodging. These limitations highlight the value of combining both modeling approaches and point to the need for further study to clarify the underlying causes of divergence.We also found that climate stresses were often interrelated between water and heat stress. The contributions of temperature anomalies to drought are difficult to disentangle48,49, and wheat yield could be influenced more by compound ECEs. The negative effects of temperature intertwined with drought were stronger on wheat but exhibited spatial variability within the study region. CHD substantially dominated yield loss in the north sub-region. This was because higher spring temperatures might affect wheat yields both through direct heat stress and through associated drought stress50. This challenge is expected to intensify with climate change, which is projected to increase the frequency and severity of heat events. In contrast, CFD contributed the most negative effects on wheat yield in the south sub-region. Although freeze events are projected to decline overall, drier atmospheric conditions and rapid development of crops may still exacerbate freeze risks, particularly under warmer daytime temperatures and clear nights51. These findings highlight the growing challenge of balancing heat and freezing risks to sustain winter wheat production under future climate scenarios.It should be noted that our analysis explicitly incorporates irrigation, as it might decouple local microclimates and regional climate patterns by altering land–atmosphere feedbacks and atmospheric moisture transport52,53. We included irrigation share as a covariate in our statistical models. We find that the estimated impacts of heat (EDD) and dry (CDD) on yield generally remain consistent in the same direction (i.e., negative impact) but are slightly larger in magnitude when irrigation is included, suggesting that omitting irrigation may lead to an underestimation of climate sensitivity. This finding is consistent with Zaveri and Lobell (2019)54, emphasizing that models excluding irrigation effects tend to provide lower-bound estimates of heat sensitivity.Uncertainties and limitationsThe impacts of ECEs on wheat yield were combined with crops and climate models. Process-based models, including CERES-Wheat, however, have obvious limitations in simulating ECEs. Models usually use the daily mean temperature instead of the daily maximum temperature to evaluate the impacts of heat stress on photosynthesis and grain filling rate; thus, the effect of heat stress on winter wheat yield is generally underestimated55. While our analysis focused on the effects of ECEs (heat, freeze, dry, and compound) on wheat yield, however, it is worth noting that crop damage from inundation or flooding was not considered. Given the rising precipitation variability and likelihood of more frequent and intense flooding events under future climate scenarios56,57,58, the exclusion of flooding effects may lead to an optimistic estimate of climate-induced yield impacts. In addition, we used consecutive dry days to serve as a drought indicator to connect with heat stress for compound hot-dry events. Low precipitation (consecutive dry days) has been widely adopted in drought assessments, and the use of compound heat-precipitation extreme events are relatively common in China16,59. However, the connections between water and heat climate extremes and their biological impacts on crops raise the potential for compound, interactive effects of changing rainfall, temperature, and soil moisture60,61. Future studies should incorporate such complementary drought metrics to better capture the complexity of drought impacts on crop productivity.ConclusionWe quantified the impacts of changes in ECEs on wheat yield in Northern China using the statistical and process-based crop models. The analysis revealed that the magnitude of yield loss due to compound ECEs was greater than that caused by individual climate events. The negative effects of temperature intertwined with drought on wheat yield varied spatiotemporally across three sub-regions. Heat and dry events caused wheat yield loss in the north and middle sub-regions, and yields were further reduced when the compound hot-dry events occurred during the reproductive phase. However, changes in compound freeze-dry events contributed to the most negative effects on wheat in the south sub-region. Future increases in heat stress were projected to cause a yield loss that substantially outweighed the yield gains from decreasing freeze stress. Future projected compound hot-dry extremes led to larger wheat yield reductions in the form of more severe ECEs with longer durations under three climate scenarios. Higher warming scenarios resulted in more pronounced yield declines in the north sub-region compared to the other sub-regions, making it the primary driver of yield changes in this wheatbelt production area. Our findings suggest that climate warming will exacerbate yield losses, particularly in the north, and highlight the need for targeted adaptation strategies. These results could assist the local winter wheat production community in implementing preventive measures to mitigate the adverse effects of climate change and enhance a better understanding of critical factors to yield improvements.MethodsWheat, phenology, and climate dataWinter wheat yield, planted area, and production data at the site level from 1999-2019 were available and retrieved from the National Bureau of Statistics (http://data.cnki.net/). Since most statistical yearbooks do not directly record per-unit yield data, the yield was obtained by dividing the total yield by and planting area. It is worth noting that all yields were calculated in units of metric kilograms per cultivated hectare (kg ha−1).Winter wheat phenological data, including sowing, anthesis, and maturity, were collected from 1992 to 2013 at 90 agro-meteorological sites operated by the China Meteorological Administration (CMA, http://data.cma.cn/en). To delineate distinct yield sensitivities to climate stresses at different development phases, we partitioned the life cycle of winter wheat into four phenological phases: germination and establishment (planting to November, GEP), dormancy (December to February, DP), vegetative (March to anthesis, VP), and reproductive (anthesis to physiological maturity, RP) phases.Observed daily climate data, including maximum, minimum, and average temperature, precipitation, and sunshine hours for 1980–2019, were obtained from the China Meteorological Administration (CMA, http://data.cma.cn/en). Daily solar radiation was calculated from observed sunshine hours using the Ångstrom formula62. Future climate scenario data of five general circulation models (GCMs) (GFDL-ESM4, MPI-ESM1-2-HR, MRI-ESM2-0, IPSL-CM6A-LR, and UKESM1-0-LL) from 2020 to 2100 were retrieved from the Intersectoral Impact Model Intercomparison Project (ISIMIP, https://data.isimip.org/search/)63. We chose ISIMIP because it is bias-adjusted and future climate data from the latest GCMs (CMIP6)64. ISIMIP found that climate variables in these five models matched historical observations better and preserved the original warming signal in CMIP665. They can well represent the entire range of GCM ensemble simulations as GFDL-ESM4, MPI-ESM1-2-HR, and MRI-ESM2-0 are low climate sensitivity, while IPSL-CM6A-LR and UKESM1-0-LL are high climate sensitivity66. We conducted future projections under 3 Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSPs): SSP1–2.6 (less than 2 °C warming; low end forcing pathway), SSP3-7.0 (around 4 °C warming; medium to high-end forcing pathway), and SSP5-8.5 (around 5 °C warming; high end forcing pathway).The climate scenario data were interpolated to the site-level by the inverse distance weighted method with a 0.5° × 0.5° horizontal resolution.Data for the rainfed and irrigated areas sown with winter wheat for the years 2000 to 2015, with a resolution of 5 arc minutes, were obtained from the global gridded dataset of annual harvested areas for the 21st century (MIRCA-OS)67. We finely interpolated grid data to the site-level to compute irrigation share at each location. The average irrigation shares for 2000 to 2015 are shown in Supplementary Fig. 5. Here, the total harvested area of winter wheat was calculated as the sum of the irrigated and rainfed wheat areas. The irrigation share (I) was then the irrigated area divided by the total harvested area at each site. Due to the absence of irrigation data, we assumed no change in irrigation share since 2015.Extreme climate indicesFive extreme climate indices were used to evaluate the impacts of ECEs on wheat yields (Table 1). Here, the individual ECEs: heat (hot days, HD) captures cumulative extreme degree days (EDD), and is defined as the number of days with Tmax above 30 °C68. For winter wheat in China, the temperature threshold of 30 °C was appropriately used for heat stress, since heat stress over 30 °C may result in reduced stomatal conductance and photosynthetic assimilation, which in turn led to a decline in grain yield formation in Chinese winter wheat69. Freeze (freeze days, FD) is the number of days when Tmin is below Tfrez during each of the four growth phases, indicating freeze stress occurrence (FDD)70,71. The Tfrez selected represents the freeze injury thresholds associated with each growth phase of wheat in China based on previous studies33,72, as detailed in Supplementary Table 2. Extreme precipitation deficit is defined as consecutive dry days (CDD) with a daily precipitation <1 mm to characterize drought stress19. Bivariate compound extreme events used are compound hot-dry days (CHD) and compound freeze-dry days (CFD), which represent heat stress or freeze stress that occurs concurrently with drought conditions during each growth phase.Table 1 Definitions of extreme degree days (EDD), freezing degree days (FDD), consecutive dry days (CDD), compound hot-dry days (CHD), and compound freeze-dry days (CFD) extreme climate indicesFull size tableEstimating effects of extreme climate indices on wheat yieldWinter wheat growth is subject to the influence of multiple extreme climate indices over distinct seasons. We developed a linear mixed-effects model to quantify the influence of extreme climate indices on wheat yield. These indices include freeze damage caused by extremely low temperatures, as well as drought and heat stresses, all of which possibly contribute to yield reductions73. Specifically, we incorporated the aforementioned climate indices, separated based on each growth phase with yield and focused on investigating how distinct extreme climatic stresses affected wheat yields. The model is specified as:$$\log {Y}_{d,t}= {\sum }_{j=2}^{3}{{\beta }_{1,j}\,{FDD}}_{d,t}^{j}{{+{\sum }_{j=3}^{4}{\beta }_{2,j}\,{{EDD}}_{d,t}^{j}+{\sum }_{j=2}^{4}{\beta }_{3,j}\,{{CDD}}_{d,t}^{j}+\beta }_{4}{CHD}}_{d,t}\\ +{\sum }_{j=2}^{3}{\beta }_{5,j}{{CFD}}_{d,t}^{j}+{\beta }_{6}{I}_{d,t}{+\alpha }_{d}+{\beta }_{7,d}t+{\beta }_{8,d}{t}^{2}{+\varepsilon }_{d,t}$$
                    (1)
                where Yd,t is winter wheat yield at site d in year t; the index j denotes one of the different phases of wheat growth season (1 = GEP, germination and establishment; 2 = DP, dormancy; 3 = VP, vegetative; 4 = RP, reproductive); αd is the site effect to control time-invariant spatial heterogeneity; the transformed yields by logarithms are primarily to stabilize the variance and interpret coefficients in percentage terms as well as to improve the normality and homogeneity of residuals; terms t and t² characterize the county-specific nonlinear but progressive technology improvements over time, which are not explained by climate; εd,t is the random error; β1–5 represents yield response to different extreme climate indices. Since wheat statistical yield data in our study region does not provide information on irrigated and rainfed yields separately, we are unable to directly estimate the impact of weather on each type. Therefore, to measure the change in sensitivity of yields to weather, we include the share of wheat-specific irrigated area (Id,t), which we use as our measure of wheat irrigation54. All variance inflation factor (VIF) values for climate predictors are summarized in Supplementary Table 3 to confirm that multicollinearity is not a concern in our model.Crop model input and calibration dataThe wheat simulation model used in this study was the CERES-Wheat model, part of the Decision Support for Agrotechnology Transfer (DSSAT). This wheat model has been widely tested and used to study diverse cropping systems around the world, along with variable climates and environments74,75. DSSAT is a point-based biophysical modeling framework to simulate crop growth as a function of weather, soil, management, and nutrient availability on a daily step basis. We simulated the wheat growth and yield on a site scale over the HHH wheatbelt for historical and future periods. DSSAT requires the following input data: (I) daily values of maximum and minimum temperature, precipitation, and solar radiation, (II) detailed soil profile data such as soil horizon depths, percentage sand, silt, and clay, bulk density, organic carbon content, pH, and soil water content; (III) management data such as planting date, planting density, planting depth, row spacing, fertilizer practices, irrigation rates, and detailed crop growth parameters. The datasets used for physical and chemical properties of soil data, including soil texture (sand, silt, and clay content), organic carbon, total N, soil bulk density, pH, drained upper limit, lower limit of available water, and saturated volumetric water content in different soil layers, were collected from the China Soil Scientific Database.We used the CERES-Wheat module to simulate wheat production. Here, irrigation was considered during model simulation. Given the spatially heterogeneous nature of irrigation across the region, the automatic irrigation setting within the model was used to approximate actual field practices. That is, wheat crop yields were simulated based on actual irrigation management practices. Crop parameters are used to set genotype aspects of wheat development. Crop parameters and physiological characteristics are given in the form of seven genetic coefficients (Supplementary Table 4). Four phenology coefficients (P1V, P1D, P5, and PHINT) impact plant phenological development, while the other three growth coefficients (G1, G2, and G3) are related to grain yield. For each winter wheat variety, model calibration was conducted based on the experimental data from one site-year experiment, and model validation was performed with data from other site-years (Supplementary Table 5). A detailed description of the calibration approach is included below. Specifically, the adjustment of the seven parameters (P1V, P1D, P5, G1, G2, G3, and PHINT) combined trial-and-error with DSSAT’s Generalized Likelihood Uncertainty Estimation (GLUE) package. First, the parameters were sequentially calibrated through stepwise calibration processes starting with phenological development to obtain a close match between simulated and observed phenology. Then the model was run with these derived crop phenological parameters, and the performance was examined in terms of wheat yields. After calibration, model accuracy was assessed by three statistical indices: mean absolute error (MAE), normalized root mean square error (NRMSE), and Willmott’s D-value index of agreement76, comparing the observed data on anthesis, maturity, and yield during the other years. CERES-Wheat with adjusted genetic parameters exhibited reliable performance for simulating winter wheat phenology from planting to anthesis (ADAT) and planting to maturity (MDAT) (Supplementary Fig. 6). The MAE values were about 4.0 and 4.7 days between simulation and observation for anthesis and maturity days, respectively. Simulated yields showed good agreement with the observations, with an MAE value of 466.7 kg ha-1. The relationship between the observed and simulated yields and phenology dates of winter wheat confirmed that the calibrated CERES-wheat model was robust in reproducing the different yield levels across a wide range of climates in China.Impacts of future climate change on wheat yieldWe used five climate models (GCMs) under three projected scenarios (SSP1-2.6, SSP3-7.0, and SSP5-8.5) to investigate how ECEs will change in the future and their potential impacts on wheat yield. To assess the extent of impacts of future climate change on wheat yield, we considered the restricted scenarios77. Specifically, we fixed the agronomic management practices at the baseline level, which represent no adaptation scenarios, while climate data were considered as actual future weather data to be employed in Eq. (1) for three scenarios from 2080 to 2100.We compared the results of the statistical model with the process-based crop model, which simulated wheat yield for the historical period at a site scale. Specifically, the crop model was driven by the CMA-observed daily climate dataset. Using the climate predictors derived from the historical period, the regression model was fitted to the yield values simulated by the crop model. The resulting series of estimated regression coefficients was then compared to the coefficients originally estimated using observed wheat yield statistics. We further applied the coefficients estimated from the crop and statistics model to GCM climate variables to project yield change. The yield changes projected with the crop model were compared with those projected with the regression model built on wheat yield data. This comparison was used to assess how well crop models simulated the extreme climate indices on wheat yield.

Data availability
              
              In this study, we utilize observed daily climate data, including maximum, minimum, and average temperature, precipitation, and sunshine hours from 1980 to 2019 acquired from the China Meteorological Administration (http://data.cma.cn/en). Future climate scenario data of five general circulation models (GCMs) (GFDL-ESM4, MPI-ESM1-2-HR, MRI-ESM2-0, IPSL-CM6A-LR, and UKESM1-0-LL) from 2080 to 2100 under SSP1-2.6, SSP3-7.0, and SSP5-8.5 were downloaded from the Intersectoral Impact Model Intercomparison Project (ISIMIP) (https://data.isimip.org/search/). The historical agricultural yield data used for our analysis was acquired from the National Bureau of Statistics (http://data.cnki.net/). Winter wheat phenological data were collected from the China Meteorological Administration (http://data.cma.cn/en). Data for the rainfed and irrigated areas sown with winter wheat with a resolution of 5 arc minutes were obtained from the global gridded dataset of annual harvested areas for the 21st century (MIRCA-OS) (https://www.nature.com/articles/s41597-024-04313-w). The observed climate, agricultural yield, and winter wheat phenological data used in this study can be found at: https://zenodo.org/records/14861192.
            Code availability
              
              The code used to perform analyses can be found at: https://zenodo.org/records/14861192.

items.title: The disappearing quasi-biennial oscillation under sustained global warming
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 29 January 2026

The disappearing quasi-biennial oscillation under sustained global warming
                    Fuhai Luo1, Fei Xie 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-2891-38831, Tianjun Zhou 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-5829-72792,3, Yingli Niu1, Yan Xia 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0001-8664-53251, Jiali Luo4, Ruhua Zhang5, Ying Wang4, Wenjun Liang 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0009-0009-7249-32316 & …Wenshou Tian 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-4700-41944 Show authors

Nature Communications

, Article number:  (2026)
            Cite this article
                    
                    
                    
                            We are providing an unedited version of this manuscript to give early access to its
                            findings. Before final publication, the manuscript will undergo further editing. Please note
                            there may be errors present which affect the content, and all legal disclaimers apply.

Subjects
        
            Atmospheric dynamicsProjection and prediction

AbstractThe stratospheric quasi-biennial oscillation (QBO) is a key modulator of interannual variability in global weather and climate. Over recent decades, the amplitude of the lower-stratospheric QBO has weakened, and in recent years the QBO has experienced unprecedented disruptions. However, the longer-term evolution of the QBO and its impact on tropospheric circulation remain uncertain. Here, based on CMIP6 models with extended projections beyond 2100 and targeted sensitivity experiments, we show that under ongoing global warming, the QBO exhibits a progressively weaker amplitude and shorter period, eventually risking complete disappearance. This is projected to reduce the predictability of 2–3-year climate forecasts in the troposphere. The weakening of the QBO amplitude arises from enhanced tropical upwelling, whereas the shortening of its period results from the combined influence of strengthened upwelling and intensified wave activity. The potential disappearance of the QBO poses new challenges for climate change under high emission.

Data availability
                  
                  The ERA5 reanalysis56 data used in this study are available in the Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) Climate Data Store57 (https://doi.org/10.24381/cds.6860a573). The CMIP6 model data42 used in this study are available in the Earth System Grid Federation (ESGF) database (https://esgf-metagrid.cloud.dkrz.de/search/cmip6-dkrz/). The HadISST data58 used in this study are available from the UK Met Office Hadley Center (http://www.metoffice.gov.uk/hadobs/hadisst/data/download.html). The sensitivity experiment outputs and the source data underlying each figure that support the findings of this Article are available in the Zenodo repository59.
               Code availability
                  
                  The code used for data analysis and figure generation in this study is available in the Zenodo repository59. The source codes for CESM1 and CESM2 are freely available from the CESM website: https://www.cesm.ucar.edu/models/releases.

items.title: Pantropical moist forests are converging towards a middle leaf longevity
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 29 January 2026

Pantropical moist forests are converging towards a middle leaf longevity
                    Meimei Xue1 na1, Xueqin Yang1,2 na1, Xiuzhi Chen 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0009-0003-5688-29971, Philippe Ciais 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0001-8560-49433, Liming Zhou 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-7009-24874, Peter B. Reich 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-4424-662X5,6, Jingfeng Xiao 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-0622-69037, Xing Li 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-2206-04298, Xiangming Xiao 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-0956-74289, Julia K. Green 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-8466-231310, Jing Ming Chen 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-8682-129311, Jane Liu11, Jiali Shang12, Xiangzhong Luo 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-9546-096013, Jie Tian1, Hui Liu 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-4027-499X14, Peng Zhu 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0001-7835-397115, Kai Yan 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-4262-177216, Xinyue Fu1, Liusheng Han17, Wenping Yuan 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-1469-439518 & …Chaoyang Wu 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0001-6163-820919 Show authors

Nature Communications

, Article number:  (2026)
            Cite this article
                    
                    
                    
                            We are providing an unedited version of this manuscript to give early access to its
                            findings. Before final publication, the manuscript will undergo further editing. Please note
                            there may be errors present which affect the content, and all legal disclaimers apply.

Subjects
        
            Climate-change impactsPhenology

AbstractLeaf longevity is a fundamental plant trait that largely explains ecosystem functional dynamics in global pantropical moist forests. However, the signs, magnitudes, and mechanisms of the spatiotemporal variations in leaf longevity with ongoing climate change are still lacking. Using both ground measurements and gridded leaf age-dependent leaf area index data, we map the continental-scale variability of annual mean leaf longevity across pantropical moist forests over 2001–2023. We find a biome-dependent and converging trend in leaf longevity under climate change. In Amazon and tropical Asia with long leaf longevity (> ~1.8 years), leaf longevity decreases due to rising temperature and intensified atmospheric dryness. In contrast, an increasing trend is observed in Congo and subtropical Asia where forests have short leaf longevity (<~1.8 years). These responses cause a convergence of pantropical short and long leaf longevity into a middle longevity range, with maximization of plant functional traits, photosynthesis, and species evenness, which are expected to better resist climate variability. Our study provides emerging evidence for large-scale structural and functional adaptions across pantropical moist forests and is helpful for predicting climate-driven risks to ecosystem stability.

Data availability
                  
                  All the relevant data in this study come from publicly available sources as follows: MODIS MCD12C1 Land Cover images: https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/mcd12c1v061/; Global Forest Watch (GFW) tree cover images: https://glad.earthengine.app/view/global-forest-change; MODIS Fire_cci Burned Area Pixel product, version 5.1: https://catalogue.ceda.ac.uk/uuid/3628cb2fdba443588155e15dee8e5352/; SPEI01 base v2.6: https://spei.csic.es/database.html; Terraclimate PDSI and Tair data: https://www.climatologylab.org/terraclimate.html; TRMM Pre data: https://disc.gsfc.nasa.gov/datasets/TRMM_3B43_7/summary?keywords=TRMM; ERA5-Land VPD data: https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/datasets/reanalysis-era5-land-monthly-means?tab=overview; Bess SW data: https://www.environment.snu.ac.kr/bess-rad; CO2 dataset: https://www.geodoi.ac.cn/edoi.aspx?DOI=10.3974/geodb.2021.11.01.V1; MODIS-GPP: https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/mod17a2hv006/; GOSIF-GPP: http://data.globalecology.unh.edu/data/GOSIF-GPP_v2/; RTSIF: https://figshare.com/articles/dataset/RTSIF_dataset/19336346/2; FLUXCOM RS + METEO GPP: https://www.bgc-jena.mpg.de/geodb/projects/Home.php; EC-LUE Model GPP: https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.8942336.v3; TL-LUE Model GPP: https://nesdc.org.cn/sdo/detail?id=671486ad7e28174998399e5d; VPM GPP: https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.c.3789814; plant functional traits map: https://pantropicalanalysis.users.earthengine.app/view/pantropical-traits-aguirre-gutierrez-2025; Ku-VOD: https://zenodo.org/records/2575599; Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF): https://www.gbif.org/zh/species/search. The leaf longevity data generated in this study have been deposited in the Figshare database under accession code: https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.30750074. All in situ data that validate the leaf longevity data of this study are available in the Supplementary Data file. Source data are provided in this paper.
